pullRequest.body:
We add 
```
def IsNonarchimedean  (f : AbsoluteValue R S) : Prop := ∀ x y : R, f (x + y) ≤ max (f x) (f y)
```
and a couple of useful lemmas.
This is going to be used in the proof of Ostrowski's Theorem for number fields.

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:

- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> Thanks! Some stylistic comments below

Thanks for the suggestions!

> Suggestions for docstrings.

Thanks!
@mariainesdff @smmercuri can you have a look? I want just to make sure we don't already have something similar. Thanks!

> @mariainesdff @smmercuri can you have a look? I want just to make sure we don't already have something similar. Thanks!

There is already an [IsNonarchimedean](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Real/Basic.html#IsNonarchimedean) definition in Mathlib for real-valued functions. Rather than adding `AbsoluteValue.IsNonarchimedean`, I think it would be better to generalize the existing Mathlib definition to
```
def IsNonarchimedean {A S : Type*} [Add A] [LinearOrderedSemiring S] (f : A → S) : Prop :=
  ∀ (r s : A), f (r + s) ≤ f r ⊔ f s
```
which would then apply in both situations. Of course, this would have to be moved out of the `Real` folder, perhaps to `Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Defs`.

> > @mariainesdff @smmercuri can you have a look? I want just to make sure we don't already have something similar. Thanks!
> 
> There is already an [IsNonarchimedean](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Real/Basic.html#IsNonarchimedean) definition in Mathlib for real-valued functions. Rather than adding `AbsoluteValue.IsNonarchimedean`, I think it would be better to generalize the existing Mathlib definition to
> 
> ```
> def IsNonarchimedean {A S : Type*} [Add A] [LinearOrderedSemiring S] (f : A → S) : Prop :=
>   ∀ (r s : A), f (r + s) ≤ f r ⊔ f s
> ```
> 
> which would then apply in both situations. Of course, this would have to be moved out of the `Real` folder, perhaps to `Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Defs`.

Thank you @mariainesdff ! I was not aware of [IsNonarchimedean](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Real/Basic.html#IsNonarchimedean). I will follow your suggestion. I will also try to generalize some/all of the results in there. I think those should go to  a new file called `Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.IsNonarchimedean` while the definition goes to `Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Defs`.
Suggestions for docstrings.
Thanks! Some stylistic comments below
Suggestions for docstrings.

```suggestion
An `AbsoluteValue` `f` is nonarchimedean if it satisfies `f (x + y) ≤ max (f x) (f y)` for all
```

```suggestion
/--An `AbsoluteValue` `f` is nonarchimedean if it satisfies `f (x + y) ≤ max (f x) (f y)` for all
```

```suggestion
  ∀ x y : R, f (x + y) ≤ max (f x) (f y)
```

I think
```suggestion
  induction s, hnonempty using Nonempty.cons_induction with
  | ...
```
should work

```suggestion
    (nonarch : IsNonarchimedean abv) (n : ℕ) : abv n ≤ 1 := by
```
assuming there's no reason to qualify this

```suggestion
  rcases h_ne.lt_or_lt with h_lt | h_lt
```

```suggestion
/-- An absolute value `f` is nonarchimedean if it satisfies `f (x + y) ≤ max (f x) (f y)` for all
`x` and `y` in `R`. -/
```

```suggestion
An absolute value `f` is nonarchimedean if it satisfies `f (x + y) ≤ max (f x) (f y)` for all
```

```suggestion
/-- Ultrametric inequality with `Finset.Sum`. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma apply_sum_le_sup_of_isNonarchimedean [AddCommMonoid R] {f : R → S}
```
If you follow my suggestion about the `IsNonarchimedean` definition, you can relax these hypotheses.
I think this can be generalized similarly as the lemma below.

This is in Mathlib for real-valued functions: [IsNonarchimedean.add_eq_max_of_ne](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Real/IsNonarchimedean.html#IsNonarchimedean.add_eq_max_of_ne).
With the new definition, I think this generalized version should hold (and it would apply to absolute values):
```suggestion
theorem add_eq_max_of_ne {F α S : Type*} [AddGroup α] [LinearOrderedCommRing S] [FunLike F α S]
    [AddGroupSeminormClass F α S] {f : F} (hna : IsNonarchimedean f) {x y : α} (h_ne : f x ≠ f y) :
    f (x + y) = max (f x) (f y)
```

```suggestion
lemma apply_natCast_le_one_of_isNonarchimedean {abv : AbsoluteValue R S}
    (nonarch : IsNonarchimedean abv) (n : ℕ) : abv n ≤ 1 := by
```
This lemma and the next are similar to [IsUltrametricDist.norm_natCast_le_one](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Ring/Ultra.html#IsUltrametricDist.norm_natCast_le_one) and [IsUltrametricDist.norm_intCast_le_one](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Ring/Ultra.html#IsUltrametricDist.norm_intCast_le_one), but given the difference in types I don't immediately see if these could be unified. In any case, I propose renaming them for consistency.

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Order/AbsoluteValue/Nonarchimedean.lean): Nonarchimedean absolute values
